title: 109_s1283
content: The "Lifespan Respite Care Act of 2005" is cited as the short title. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section on Lifespan Respite Care, with findings and purposes outlined. Congress finds that millions of individuals in the United States require caregiving for various chronic illnesses, disabilities, and conditions, including adults, children, individuals with developmental disabilities, and elders with multiple chronic disabling conditions. Approximately 600,000 Americans die at home annually, many relying on family caregivers. 42 percent of individuals needing daily assistance in the US are under 65. Family caregivers face emotional, physical, and financial hardships. If their services were replaced with paid workers, it would cost $200 billion yearly. The text chunk highlights the challenges faced by family caregivers in accessing respite care programs due to limited availability and lack of trained workers. The purpose of the title is to encourage the establishment of state and local respite care programs, improve information dissemination, and provide or enhance respite care services to family caregivers. The text chunk emphasizes the need to promote innovative approaches to delivering respite care, recruit and train respite care workers and volunteers, and provide training programs for family caregivers. It also aims to support research on effective respite care services and disseminate findings related to respite care delivery and caregiver strain. The curr_chunk focuses on training programs for family caregivers to help them make informed decisions about respite care services. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to respite care services for family caregivers. The curr_chunk defines an eligible recipient as a State agency, public entity, nonprofit organization, political subdivision, or State respite coordinating agency with specific capabilities and criteria. The curr_chunk defines terms related to individuals with special needs, including adults and children requiring care or supervision for basic needs or to prevent injury. It also defines a family caregiver as someone providing care to a family member. The curr_chunk defines terms related to individuals with special needs, including family caregivers, respite care, and lifespan respite care for children and adults with special needs. The curr_chunk focuses on Lifespan Respite Care Grants and Cooperative Agreements. The section authorizes grants to expand respite care services for family caregivers, improve dissemination and coordination, and enhance access and quality of services. The Secretary can award grants to eligible recipients who apply, working with various agencies to implement the program. The Administration on Developmental Disabilities, Maternal and Child Health Bureau, and Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration coordinate respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Eligible recipients must submit an application to the Secretary detailing their understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues. The Administration on Developmental Disabilities, Maternal and Child Health Bureau, and Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration coordinate respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs. Eligible recipients must submit an application to the Secretary detailing their understanding of respite care and family caregiver issues. The application should include capacity for family involvement, collaboration with other agencies, description of family caregivers, and their respite care needs. Existing respite care services for family caregivers of individuals with special needs are coordinated at the State and local level. This includes information dissemination, service coordination, recruitment and training programs for respite care workers and volunteers, and training programs for family caregivers to make informed decisions about respite care services. The curr_chunk discusses the plan for collaboration and coordination of respite care activities with other related services, involvement of the population in planning and implementation, and maximizing the use of funds for respite care services. The curr_chunk focuses on utilizing various resources such as Federal, State, and local funds, programs, and facilities for respite care services. It also addresses the availability of respite care services for family caregivers, criteria for eligibility, and ensuring quality and safety. The curr_chunk discusses monitoring the quality and safety of respite care services, screening workers and volunteers, evaluating results of respite care activities, and maintaining confidentiality of care recipient and family caregiver records. The Secretary establishes a panel to review applications for grants or cooperative agreements. The panel evaluates each application and makes recommendations to the Secretary for approval. Grants or cooperative agreements are awarded based on the panel's recommendations. When awarding grants or cooperative agreements, the Secretary prioritizes applicants likely to implement or enhance lifespan respite care statewide. Recipients must use funds for developing respite care at state and local levels and evaluating its effectiveness. The recipient awarded a grant/cooperative agreement can use funds for respite care services, worker training, and caregiver programs. Funds must be used for evaluating the effectiveness of the activities. The eligible recipient awarded a grant/cooperative agreement can subcontract with a public or nonprofit agency to carry out activities. Grants or agreements awarded under this section have a maximum term of 5 years and can be renewed. Funds must supplement, not supplant, other available federal, state, and local funds for respite care services. Authorization of Appropriations: Sums may be appropriated for fiscal years 2006 through 2010 for respite care services. The National Lifespan Respite Resource Center, established through a grant or cooperative agreement, aims to maintain a national database on respite care, offer training and assistance to various programs, and provide information and education to the public. Authorization of appropriations is available for fiscal years 2006 through 2010.
